Unless you have a custom object with customÂ .toStringÂ method returningÂ JSON.stringifyÂ of that object, there is noÂ objÂ that would giveÂ obj.toString() == JSON.stringify(obj). WhenÂ objÂ is an array likeÂ [1,2,3]Â thenÂ .toString()Â gives: 
"1,2,3"
AndÂ JSON.stringify: 
"[1,2,3]"
These are close but not quite the same, the JSON serialized one has no ambiguity with commas and directly runs as Javascript or can be parsed as JSON.
Jacob Georgeï¼š
for an object say 
obj = { a: 'a', '1': 1 }
obj.toString()Â gives 
"[object Object]"
JSON.stringify(obj)Â gives 
"{"1":1,"a":"a"}"
ForÂ .toString(), a default value is returned when the argument type is an object.Â JSON.stringifyÂ on the other hand returns JSON text, which can be converted back into a JSON object by usingJSON.parse
